title: Post With Code
text:
Lets work some code into the blog and test it.

# check functions
print("hello world!")

hello world!



# test math
2+2

4



import warnings 
warnings.filterwarnings("ignore", category=UserWarning, module="palmerpenguins")
from palmerpenguins import load_penguins
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

penguins_df = load_penguins()
penguins_cleaned_df = penguins_df.dropna()

species_counts = penguins_cleaned_df['species'].value_counts()

Show Matplotlib Charts

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plot = plt.figure()
plot.set_figwidth(6)
plot.set_figheight(3)

plt.bar(species_counts.index, species_counts.values)









plot.savefig("matplotlib_bar.png")

title: Public Lab Book
text:
This blog is a living notebook. I’m building it with Quarto, running everything locally, publishing what works, and keeping the rest as a record of experiments. Expect a mix of notebooks, short writeups, reproducible code, and honest failure notes — part documentation, part exploration, part “let’s see what happens when I push this button.”
I’m doing this out loud because the process matters as much as the result. Posts will range from quick riffs and reproducible demos to deeper walkthroughs of pipelines and models. The goal is practical clarity: show what I tried, what broke, and what I learned.
What you’ll find here
# Experiments and demos: runnable Quarto notebooks and small projects you can clone and try.
# Notes and reflections: concise writeups that capture intuition, tradeoffs, and next steps.
# How‑tos and patterns: practical recipes for data modelling, pipelines, migrations, and CI/CD.
# Failures and fixes: debugging threads and postmortems so others don’t repeat the same mistakes.
About me
I build practical, data‑led solutions and enjoy getting stuck into messy problems until they make sense. I turn fragmented feeds and brittle rules into a single, reliable flow people can trust. I lead and coach teams, run reviews and roadmaps, and I’m happiest rolling up my sleeves to remove blockers and get things over the line.
On the technical side I work with data modelling, modern data pipelines and migration workflows, Python, SQL, version control, and CI/CD. I’m sharpening my analytics skills through a Data Science and AI course and I prototype quickly to test ideas in the real world. I’m a clear communicator, a self‑starter, and I like helping others learn so improvements stick.
How I work
I favor small, testable experiments over long, speculative plans. Each post aims to be reproducible and actionable: code, notes, and the minimal context needed to run or adapt the work. When something is exploratory, I’ll label it as such; when it’s a pattern I trust, I’ll call that out too.
Join the experiment
If you’re curious about machine learning, data engineering, AI, or agentic systems, you’ll find something useful here — or at least a clear record of what didn’t work. Subscribe to the feed, fork the notebooks, or drop a comment on a post. I’m here with curiosity, a stack of experiments, and zero certainty about where this path leads. Which is exactly the point.

title: Copilot - changes for the Credit Relationship Manager
text:
It’s the difference between looking things up and having things done. Search engines gives you information however Copilot gives you work already in motion. Instead of just fetching data, showing documents or answering questions, it interprets, drafts, prepares and prioritizes work and helps the relationship manager find time in their busy schedule. Below are some of the things that keeps them busy and we will provide a short guide to showcase what copilot can offer.







UseCase



actor1

Credit RM



uc1

Client Preparation & Research



actor1->uc1





uc2

Credit Analysis & Underwriting Support



actor1->uc2





uc3

Credit Memo & Documentation



actor1->uc3





uc4

Client Communication & Follow‑ups



actor1->uc4





uc5

Portfolio Monitoring & Early Warning



actor1->uc5





uc6

Internal Collaboration & Workflow Efficiency



actor1->uc6










Here are a few prompts that instantly make a relationship manager’s workflow lighter, faster, and sharper than working without Copilot. And this is just the beginning. Using Copilot is the first real step toward becoming an AI‑first organization by building everyday comfort with LLMs, strengthening intuition around model‑driven workflows, and setting the stage for deeper AI integration across credit, risk, and client engagement. Along with this initiative one can investigate agentic ai for the credit committee process which is repetitive and also involves may stakeholders.

Client Preparation & Research - RMs spend a huge amount of time gathering context before meetings. Copilot can compress that into minutes. What Copilot can do:

Summarize long financial statements into key trends, ratios, and red flags
Extract borrower risk indicators from PDFs or emails
Generate concise borrower profiles from scattered documents
Create comparison tables across years, products, or subsidiaries
Draft meeting briefs with “what to ask” and “what to watch for”

Example prompt: Summarize this borrower’s last 3 years of financials and highlight liquidity, leverage, and cash flow concerns. Create a 5‑bullet brief for my meeting.
Credit Analysis & Underwriting Support - Copilot won’t replace credit judgment, but it dramatically accelerates the analytical grunt work. What Copilot can do:

Calculate ratios from raw financials
Generate sensitivity scenarios (e.g., revenue drop, interest rate increase)
Draft the narrative sections of credit memos
Translate analyst‑speak into executive‑ready summaries
Identify missing data or inconsistencies

Example prompt: “Calculate DSCR, FCCR, and leverage ratios from this data. Then write a credit narrative explaining the borrower’s risk profile in plain language.”
Credit Memo & Documentation - This is where RMs lose the most time. Copilot can turn rough notes into polished documents. What Copilot can do:

Draft full credit memos from bullet points
Rewrite sections for clarity, tone, or regulatory alignment
Generate executive summaries tailored to credit committees
Convert messy emails into structured documentation
Create checklists for required documents

Example prompt: “Turn these notes into a clean, structured credit memo with sections for business overview, financial analysis, risks, mitigants, and recommendation.”
Client Communication & Follow‑ups - RMs spend hours writing emails. Copilot can handle 80% of that. What Copilot can do:

Draft professional emails in seconds
Rewrite messages in different tones (formal, concise, empathetic)
Generate follow‑up reminders
Create client‑ready explanations of complex credit terms
Translate communications into multiple languages

Example prompt: “Draft a concise email explaining why we need updated financials and how it affects their credit review timeline.”
Portfolio Monitoring & Early Warning - Copilot can act like a lightweight monitoring engine. What Copilot can do:

Summarize covenant breaches or near‑breaches
Flag unusual trends in borrower performance
Generate monthly or quarterly portfolio summaries
Draft early‑warning alerts for internal teams
Create dashboards or tables from raw data

Example prompt: “Review these covenant calculations and highlight any breaches or trends that require escalation.”
Internal Collaboration & Workflow Efficiency - RMs often coordinate across credit, legal, risk, and operations. Copilot reduces friction. What Copilot can do:

Turn meeting notes into action items
Draft internal memos or escalation summaries
Create structured handoffs for credit analysts
Rewrite technical content for non‑technical stakeholders
Generate templates for recurring workflows

Example prompt: “Convert these meeting notes into a clear action plan with owners, deadlines, and risks.”

title: A Historical Roadmap of Mathematics, Statistics, and Machine Learning
text:
Introduction
Modern machine learning did not appear suddenly. It is the product of a long intellectual lineage spanning probability theory, statistical inference, optimization, and computational breakthroughs. This roadmap traces that evolution -

timeline
    title History of Mathematics, Statistics, and Machine Learning
    1600s : Pascal & Fermat formalize probability
          : John Graunt creates first life tables
    1700s : Bernoulli proves Law of Large Numbers
          : Bayes' Theorem published (1763)
    1800s : Legendre introduces least squares
          : Gauss formalizes normal distribution
          : Galton & Pearson develop correlation and regression
          : Markov introduces Markov chains
    1900s : Fisher develops maximum likelihood and ANOVA
          : Neyman–Pearson hypothesis testing
          : Turing formalizes computation
          : Rosenblatt invents the perceptron
          : Backpropagation rediscovered (1986)
          : CART decision trees (1984)
          : SVMs and kernel methods (1990s)
          : Ensemble methods (bagging, boosting, stacking)
    2000s : Deep learning resurgence with GPUs
          : CNNs, RNNs, LSTMs mature
    2010s : Transformers and large-scale pretraining
    2020s : Foundation models, diffusion models, agentic workflows

source - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_statistics#Introduction
